attributes.title: Genetic Predispositions and Caregiving Behaviour interact in modulating Virtual Social Attitudes in Humans
attributes.description: The interaction between parental care and the oxytocin receptor (OXTR) gene affect social behaviours in adulthood. Serotonin transporter gene polymorphisms (5-HTTLPR) and early parent-infant interaction influence adults’ relationship with intimate partners. However, human conspecifics socially act towards the real and virtual world in displaying multiple and complex social interactions. Hence, the mechanisms underlying the virtual social relationship in humans remain largely unknown. We hypothesized interaction between genetic factors (three polymorphisms from the oxytocin receptor, OXTR, and the serotonin transporter, 5-HTTLPR), parental bonding patterns (PBI) and adults’ interactional patterns (ASQ, ECR-R) in shaping virtual social behaviour (Instagram, Facebook). Self-reported questionnaires were used to evaluate participants’ (n= 61) parental bonding patterns (Parental Bonding Instrument, formed by four subscales Maternal Care, Paternal Care, Maternal Overprotection, Paternal Overprotection), interactional patterns towards peers (Attachment Style Questionnaire formed by five subscales Confidence, Discomfort in Intimacy, Relationship as Secondary, Need for Approval, Worry about Relationship) and the quality of bond with intimate partners (Experience in Close Relationship Scale formed by two subscales Anxiety, Avoidance). Social media activities were collected applying an automatic Python algorithm through which eight indexes were extracted: Instagram number of following users, followers, posts and tags from other users’ posts and Facebook number of friends, interests, published pics and given likes. Buccal mucosa cell samples were collected to assess participants’ genetic predispositions, and regions OXTR/rs2254298 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers), OXTR/rs53576 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) and 5-HTTLPR/rs255331 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) were genotyped. We hypothesize multiple gene*environment interactions on different parameters and indexes calculated on the social media variables as Instagram Followers/Following ratio (“Social Desirability Index”).

q1.value: A potential interaction between genetic predispositions and adult attachment patterns on Facebook behaviour

q2.value: Andrea Bonassi, Alessandro Carollo, Ilaria Cataldo, Giulio Gabrieli, Bruno Lepri, Gianluca Esposito

q3.value: In the existing literature, it is not clear whether the bases of social interactions are universally or specifically defined between real and virtual social environments. For instance, Oldmeadow et al. (2013) reported that adult attachment patterns are related to online social activity, openness and attitudes towards Facebook. However, it is not clear the role played by the genetic factors combined with adult attachment in moderating Facebook social behaviour. Our research aims to investigate the interaction between genetic factors (OXTr/rs2254298, OXTr/rs53576) and adult attachment patterns (Experiences in Close Relationships) on the modulation of virtual social behaviour on Facebook (number of friends). This study intends to examine if the specific interaction between genes and environment (adult attachment patterns) modulates Facebook social behaviour in vulnerable genetic carriers.

q4.value:
We hypothesize an interaction between genetic factors and attachment pattern scores (ECR-R) on Facebook number of friends. Specifically, (1) adult Facebook users with genetic risk factors (OXTr rs224529 A carriers, OXTr rs53576 G carriers) and positive relationship with the partner (low scores of avoidance and anxiety in ECR-R) would show higher number of friends compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers (OXTr rs224529 G/G homozygotes, OXTr rs53576 A/A homozygotes). Vice-versa, (2) adult Facebook users with genetic risk factor and negative relationship with the partner (high scores of avoidance and anxiety in ECR-R) would show a lower number of friends compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers.
We think Facebook number of friends is a significant variable to test in our hypothesis. Furthermore, we think the number of friends is the most significant variable on Facebook because it indicates the number of users involved in a virtual relationship. Having only one primary-dependent variable allows us to maintain a conservative approach to data and to avoid extreme corrections due to multiple tests comparison.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a mixed design study with Facebook social behaviour (number of friends) values as the dependent variable, the OXTr gene genotype (OXTr rs224529 G/G homozygotes vs A carriers, OXTr rs53576 A/A homozygotes vs G carriers) as a between-subject factor, and the ECR dimensions (anxiety and avoidance) as continuous covariates.

q9.value: This study will not require randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Existing data were organized and processed in a database by two researchers. The final dataframe will be accessible to two researchers.

question.value:
A) Before the experiment, each participant signed the informed consent (no-risk warranty, health history and data treatment) and provided the information about their demographic details (age, gender, ethnicity).
B) For the behavioural assessment of the research, each participant compiled an online self-report questionnaire (Experiences in Close Relationships) to assess their adult attachment with the partner (level of avoidance and anxiety).
C) For the genetic assessment, a buccal mucosa sample of DNA was collected from each of the participants by using a sterile cotton swab for genotyping.
D) For the social media assessment, each participant provided their own Facebook link and researchers, using an ad-hoc Python script, obtained a parameter representative of the virtual social behaviour (number of friends on Facebook). Where the automatic script failed, Facebook data were collected manually, whenever it was possible (e.g., non-private profile).

q13.value: Non-parent adults (n = 61) aged 18-26 were recruited among the students of the Nanyang Technological University (Singapore). All participants were Singaporean. The exclusion criteria were: (I) current or lifetime history of psychiatric, neurological or genetic disorders, (II) not having a Facebook account, (III) being older than 30 years. Twenty-one participants were excluded from the analysis because of failures in: a) the collection of their Facebook data or b) their questionnaire compilation. The final sample consisted of 40 Singaporean users (11 males) with their number of friends on Facebook. The Ethical Committee of Nanyang Technological University approved the research (IRB-2015-08-020-01). The study was conducted following the Declaration of Helsinki. Bio-samples containing buccal mucosa were anonymized and sent to the laboratory for genetic assessment. Facebook and questionnaire data were anonymized at the beginning of the data collection.

q14.value: The study constraints affected the sample size of the research. For this reason, we calculated the effect size by implementing a Sensitivity power analysis in GPower software for Facebook number of friends. In the Sensitivity Analysis, we considered analysis of covariance (ANCOVA: fixed effects, main effects and interactions). Input parameters fixed the alpha at 0.05, Power at 0.80, total sample size at 40, numerator degrees of freedom at 1, number of groups at 2, number of covariates at 2. After the calculation, the output parameters showed a large effect size. This result is consistent with previous studies which found a large effect size (for example, see Bonassi et al., 2019). Furthermore, we will use two Student's t-tests in order to study the interaction effect between adult attachment pattern and genotype. Considering that the researchers have not yet been allowed to access the dataset, it is not possible to know the sample sizes of the two comparing groups in order to conduct a sensitivity analysis (corrected alpha at 0.025, expected Power at 0.80). Thus, we will conduct post-hoc analysis in order to calculate the power of the one-tailed Student's t-tests (the difference between two independent means), for each significant gene*environment interaction.

q15.value: As many participants as possible were recruited in three months.

question.value: As an observational study, this research did not include manipulated variables.

The study’s hypothesis-driven measured variables included genetic, environmental, and Facebook data.
A detailed description of the measured genetic and environmental variables is provided:
1) Environmental measure: adult attachment patterns. The Experiences in Close Relationships (ECR-R) is a 36-item self-report questionnaire with responses in a 7-points scale commonly adopted to assess attachment patterns in a variety of close relationships. Two ECR-R Dimensions were evaluated and considered: 
a) Anxiety is an integer variable which reports the ECR scores for anxious attachment.
b) Avoidance is an integer variable which describes the ECR scores for avoidance attachment.
2) Genetic measure: Oxytocin Receptor Gene. We examined the regions rs2245298 and rs53576 of the Oxytocin Receptor Gene (OXTr) because of their previously tested relation with social behaviour, empathy, affect and attachment.
a) OXTr rs53576 is a categorical variable (levels: A/A, A/G, G/G) which contains the genotypes for the OXTr region rs53576.
b) OXTr 2254298 is a categorical variable (levels: A/A, G/A, G/G) which includes the genotypes for the OXTr region 2254298.
3) A web-scraper implemented in Python extracted an a priori parameter representative of the Facebook (FB) social behaviour. 
a) FB friends is an integer variable which describes the Facebook number of friends. This parameter is the only measured dependent variable included in the confirmatory analyses of this study.
The variable extracted from Facebook represents a description of Facebook social behaviour of the participant at a specific point in the timeline. No further indexes will be calculated.

In this study, we expect two genotype*environment interactions (OXTr rs2254298 SNP * attachment patterns and OXTr rs53576 SNP * attachment patterns) on the number of friends. The genetic variables, OXTr rs2245298 and OXTr rs53576 will be used in separate analyses as predictors of FB number of friends, while the ECR-R subscales will be considered as covariates. We will run the statistical analysis by using R software. 
Data approach and statistical analysis will follow these steps:
a) After having imported the dataset into R, we will quantify the NA values for each variable.
b) Data of subjects with NA values greater than 2 will be excluded from the analysis.
c) Genotype frequencies for the regions OXTr rs53576 (A/A vs A/G vs G/G) and rs2254298 (A/A, G/A, G/G) will be calculated.
d) Participants carrying at least one allele (i.e. G/G homozygotes or A/G) will be classified into a single carrier group, and the obtained genotype distribution (i.e. A/A homozygotes vs G carriers) will be compared with the Hardy–Weinberg Equilibrium.
e) Facebook variable (number of friends) will be standardized through the use of z-scores.
f) Male and female participants will be checked for significant differences between the allelic groups and within each FB variable. 
g) In our sample, for each subscale of the ECR-R questionnaire, we will calculate Cronbach's alphas.
h) Prior to data analysis, the data distribution of the dependent variable will be displayed by density plots and box-plots; skew and kurtosis will be calculated to understand the related power values. 
i) We will apply a logarithmic transformation to the dependent variable if the sampling will not show a Gaussian distribution. Then, a statistical parametric test will be adopted.
j) Bartlett test will verify the preliminary assumption of equal variance across the sample for an Analysis of Variance (univariate and multivariate ANOVA and ANCOVA) family test.
k) For each Facebook variable an ANCOVA will be run with the Facebook measure as the dependent variable, the OXTr gene genotype (OXTr rs224529 G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) as a between-subjects factor and the ECR-R dimensions all together (anxiety and avoidance) as continuous covariates. For each Facebook variable, an ANCOVA will be also performed with the OXTr gene genotype rs53576 (A/A vs G carriers) as a between-subjects factor, with the other parameters unvaried.
l) If we will find a significant gender effect in the preliminary analysis, the variable "Gender" will be included as a between-subjects factor in the ANCOVA
m) Correlation will be run as post-hoc tests, and we will use Pearsons’ r coefficient to analyze the strength of the effect of the covariate on the dependent variable, while Cohen’s d will be used to evaluate the magnitude of effects which will be found to be significant.
n) Scores in the dimensions of anxiety and avoidance are a continuum, which will enable us to identify the ECR-R subscales 1) as covariates applied to the ANCOVA, 2) as four main groups by clustering the sample using the median splits for the post-hoc tests: high avoidance, high anxiety, low avoidance, low anxiety.
o) Main and interactive ANCOVA effects between variables will be considered, visualized as scatterplots with linear models.
p) Effects of the interaction between attachment patterns and genotype on the FB number of friends will be represented by bar plots and further analyzed by post-hoc t-tests.

q20.value: If the dependent variable is not resulting in Gaussian data distribution, it will be converted with a log-transformation, in order to carry out statistical parametric tests. If the log-transformation will not convert the data into a Gaussian curve with the value of the skew parameter contained between -1.5 and 1.5, we will consider the cubic root data transformation.

q21.value: The probability value for the given parametric statistical models (ANCOVAs) will be used to determine the statistical significance of the results. One-tailed post-hoc Student's t-test will be preferable if the direction of the effect is clear and in line with the previous hypotheses; otherwise, two-tailed post-hoc t-tests will be used. Alpha will be corrected proportionally to the number of repeated t-tests by Bonferroni method. Moreover, Cohen’s d will be calculated to evaluate the magnitude of significant effects in the ANCOVAs. Finally, regression coefficients will be applied to analyze the effects of the covariates on the dependent variable.

q22.value: For each dependent variable, all the data-points which differ from the mean by 2 or more deviations standard will be considered as outliers and substituted with the value of the mean calculated among all the other values excluding the outliers.

q23.value: For each variable of each subject, incomplete or missing data will be removed from subsequent analyses.

q24.value: Exploratory analysis are not planned for this study.

attributes.title: Hormonal Influences on Attraction and Visual Attention to Masculinity

q1.value: Hormonal Influences on Attraction and Visual Attention to Masculinity

q3.value: The proposed study aims to address issues raised by previous studies investigating the ovulatory shift hypothesis by using an eye tracking paradigm to track women’s visual preferences to sexually dimorphic faces. Therefore, this proposal seeks to address research questions raised by previous studies and answer whether shifts across the menstrual cycle are detected through eye movements (Burris et al., 2014).

q4.value:
1). It is hypothesized that as estradiol increases and progesterone decreases (i.e., high E/P ratio), women will display an attentional bias towards masculine faces.
2). It is hypothesized that women during peak fertility  (i.e., high E/P ratio) will display an attentional bias to masculine faces when considering men for a short-term relationship. 
3). It is predicted that women with a high perceived mate value may be more competitive for accessing men that display high quality traits.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Although this is not an experiment, but a within-subjects design,  personnel involved in the project will not know the true nature of what is being tested.

question.value: The study design is a repeated measures design. Participants will be women from a Midwestern University. They will be asked to sign up during three time points of their menstrual cycle, 1). menstruation- day 6. 2). Late follicular days 6-14, and 3). Post-follicular,days  14- onset of menstruation. They will view images of men whose faces have been manipulated to appear masculine and feminine. These images will be presented simultaneously, and their eye movements will be tracked as women scan the images. There will be one block of trials where participants are to view the men for a short-term relationship, and another block of trials where participants are to view the men for a long-term relationship. For each session (e.g., 3 sessions total), participants will provide a saliva sample using passive drool collection in a 1.5mL vial tube, in which the hormones estradiol and progesterone will be assayed. In addition to each session, we will collect measures of short-term mating (SOI-R), life-history (mini-k), mate value, and sexual desire. Participants will also provide numerical ratings (likert scale) of attraction for each image after the eye tracking procedure.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: The population are women from a Midwestern University. They are women between the ages of 18-40, and they must not be on any hormonal based birth control. We are only recruiting women who identify primarily as hetereosexual. Each participant is credited 1 sona credit for each session. Participants must complete the study within one month in which they signed up for the three sessions.

q13.value:
A power analysis for a 2 (Sexual Dimorphism: Masculine/Feminine) x 2 (Mating: Short/Long) x 3 time session (Time: 1/2/3) within subjects design indicated a sample size of 71 participants in order to detect a small to medium effect size (B = .80, f= .10) using g power. 
Since we are using a multi-level design, we are collecting 40 observations per participant, per session, ( 20 trials per block of mating).

q14.value: Stated above in the sample size box.

q15.value: We will stop at a little over 71 participants, due to the possibility of missing data in the eye tracking study.

question.value:
The manipulated variables are the mating context, short vs. long-term mating. The short term mating context is a prompt taken from Little et al. (2007), where participants are to imagine that they are looking for men for a short-term relationships: :You are looking for the type of person who would be attractive in a short-term relationship. This implies that the relationship may not last a long time. Examples of this type of relationship would include a single date accepted on the spur of the moment, an affair within a long-term".

Long-term: "u are looking for the type of person who would be attractive in a long-term relationship. Examples of this type of relationship would include someone you may want to move in with, someone you may consider leaving a current partner to be with, and someone you may, at some point, wish to marry (or enter into a relationship on similar grounds as marriage)."

The manipulated faces are male faces from the London face lab. They include faces that are manipulated to include features that are 50% masculine and 50% feminine.

The outcome variables will be attraction, measured on a 7 point likert scale to indicate '1=unattractive', to '7= extremely attractive'.
First fixation Duration= This is defined as the duration of the first fixation in millieseconds, and it is often used as an indicator of early onset processing. 
Fixation count= This is defined as a measure of looking frequency, and it is the number of fixations made on an image (i.e., masculine vs feminine men). 
Total fixation duration= This is an aggregate amount of time used to indicate the amount of time overall spent viewing each male manipulation (masculine/feminine).

For all hypotheses, participants (i.e., subjects) and time (i.e., visit 1, 2, 3) will be entered as random effects. Using a multilevel model provides many benefits in repeated measures designs as it accounts for correlated error across observations (i.e., subjects) and time (i.e., visits). 
For hypothesis 1, where it is hypothesized that as estradiol is high and progesterone is low (i.e., high E/P ratio), women will display an attentional bias towards masculine faces, progesterone, estradiol, E/P ratio, and sexually dimorphic faces will be the entered as the predictors, while subjects and time (i.e., visit 1, 2, 3) will be entered as random effects. From there, we will test if random slopes for sexual dimorphism and hormonal measures improve model fit by using the "lower is better" rule in AIC model selection for linear mixed effects models. 
The second hypothesis predicts that women in the short-term mating context will display preferences for masculinity during peak fertility. Estradiol, progesterone, E/P ratio, masculinity, and mating context will be entered as predictors, while subjects and time will be entered as random effects. From there, we will test if random slopes for sexual dimorphism, mating context, and hormonal measures improve model fit by using the "lower is better" rule in AIC model selection for linear mixed effects models. 
The third hypothesis, women with a high perceived mate value may be more competitive for accessing men that display high quality traits. For this hypothesis, the self-perceived mate value scale and sexually dimorphic faces will be entered as predictors, and total dwell time will be entered as the dependent variable.

q23.value: One of the reasons for using a linear mixed effects model (LME) is for the possibility of missing cases. Missing cases are handled better in a multi-level model, and it is often recommended for such issues in data.

q24.value: Some exploratory analysis will be to investigate individual differences in Short-term mating orientation and sexual desire as it relates to visual attention to dimorphic faces.

registration_responses.q1: Hormonal Influences on Attraction and Visual Attention to Masculinity
registration_responses.q3: The proposed study aims to address issues raised by previous studies investigating the ovulatory shift hypothesis by using an eye tracking paradigm to track women’s visual preferences to sexually dimorphic faces. Therefore, this proposal seeks to address research questions raised by previous studies and answer whether shifts across the menstrual cycle are detected through eye movements (Burris et al., 2014).
registration_responses.q4:
1). It is hypothesized that as estradiol increases and progesterone decreases (i.e., high E/P ratio), women will display an attentional bias towards masculine faces.
2). It is hypothesized that women during peak fertility  (i.e., high E/P ratio) will display an attentional bias to masculine faces when considering men for a short-term relationship. 
3). It is predicted that women with a high perceived mate value may be more competitive for accessing men that display high quality traits.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q7: Although this is not an experiment, but a within-subjects design,  personnel involved in the project will not know the true nature of what is being tested.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q13:
A power analysis for a 2 (Sexual Dimorphism: Masculine/Feminine) x 2 (Mating: Short/Long) x 3 time session (Time: 1/2/3) within subjects design indicated a sample size of 71 participants in order to detect a small to medium effect size (B = .80, f= .10) using g power. 
Since we are using a multi-level design, we are collecting 40 observations per participant, per session, ( 20 trials per block of mating).
registration_responses.q14: Stated above in the sample size box.
registration_responses.q15: We will stop at a little over 71 participants, due to the possibility of missing data in the eye tracking study.
registration_responses.q23: One of the reasons for using a linear mixed effects model (LME) is for the possibility of missing cases. Missing cases are handled better in a multi-level model, and it is often recommended for such issues in data.
registration_responses.q24: Some exploratory analysis will be to investigate individual differences in Short-term mating orientation and sexual desire as it relates to visual attention to dimorphic faces.
registration_responses.q8.question: The study design is a repeated measures design. Participants will be women from a Midwestern University. They will be asked to sign up during three time points of their menstrual cycle, 1). menstruation- day 6. 2). Late follicular days 6-14, and 3). Post-follicular,days  14- onset of menstruation. They will view images of men whose faces have been manipulated to appear masculine and feminine. These images will be presented simultaneously, and their eye movements will be tracked as women scan the images. There will be one block of trials where participants are to view the men for a short-term relationship, and another block of trials where participants are to view the men for a long-term relationship. For each session (e.g., 3 sessions total), participants will provide a saliva sample using passive drool collection in a 1.5mL vial tube, in which the hormones estradiol and progesterone will be assayed. In addition to each session, we will collect measures of short-term mating (SOI-R), life-history (mini-k), mate value, and sexual desire. Participants will also provide numerical ratings (likert scale) of attraction for each image after the eye tracking procedure.
registration_responses.q12.question: The population are women from a Midwestern University. They are women between the ages of 18-40, and they must not be on any hormonal based birth control. We are only recruiting women who identify primarily as hetereosexual. Each participant is credited 1 sona credit for each session. Participants must complete the study within one month in which they signed up for the three sessions.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The manipulated variables are the mating context, short vs. long-term mating. The short term mating context is a prompt taken from Little et al. (2007), where participants are to imagine that they are looking for men for a short-term relationships: :You are looking for the type of person who would be attractive in a short-term relationship. This implies that the relationship may not last a long time. Examples of this type of relationship would include a single date accepted on the spur of the moment, an affair within a long-term".

Long-term: "u are looking for the type of person who would be attractive in a long-term relationship. Examples of this type of relationship would include someone you may want to move in with, someone you may consider leaving a current partner to be with, and someone you may, at some point, wish to marry (or enter into a relationship on similar grounds as marriage)."

The manipulated faces are male faces from the London face lab. They include faces that are manipulated to include features that are 50% masculine and 50% feminine.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The outcome variables will be attraction, measured on a 7 point likert scale to indicate '1=unattractive', to '7= extremely attractive'.
First fixation Duration= This is defined as the duration of the first fixation in millieseconds, and it is often used as an indicator of early onset processing. 
Fixation count= This is defined as a measure of looking frequency, and it is the number of fixations made on an image (i.e., masculine vs feminine men). 
Total fixation duration= This is an aggregate amount of time used to indicate the amount of time overall spent viewing each male manipulation (masculine/feminine).
registration_responses.q19.question:
For all hypotheses, participants (i.e., subjects) and time (i.e., visit 1, 2, 3) will be entered as random effects. Using a multilevel model provides many benefits in repeated measures designs as it accounts for correlated error across observations (i.e., subjects) and time (i.e., visits). 
For hypothesis 1, where it is hypothesized that as estradiol is high and progesterone is low (i.e., high E/P ratio), women will display an attentional bias towards masculine faces, progesterone, estradiol, E/P ratio, and sexually dimorphic faces will be the entered as the predictors, while subjects and time (i.e., visit 1, 2, 3) will be entered as random effects. From there, we will test if random slopes for sexual dimorphism and hormonal measures improve model fit by using the "lower is better" rule in AIC model selection for linear mixed effects models. 
The second hypothesis predicts that women in the short-term mating context will display preferences for masculinity during peak fertility. Estradiol, progesterone, E/P ratio, masculinity, and mating context will be entered as predictors, while subjects and time will be entered as random effects. From there, we will test if random slopes for sexual dimorphism, mating context, and hormonal measures improve model fit by using the "lower is better" rule in AIC model selection for linear mixed effects models. 
The third hypothesis, women with a high perceived mate value may be more competitive for accessing men that display high quality traits. For this hypothesis, the self-perceived mate value scale and sexually dimorphic faces will be entered as predictors, and total dwell time will be entered as the dependent variable.

attributes.title: Genetic Predispositions and Caregiving Behaviour interact in modulating Virtual Social Attitudes in Humans
attributes.description: The interaction between parental care and the oxytocin receptor (OXTR) gene affect social behaviours in adulthood. Serotonin transporter gene polymorphisms (5-HTTLPR) and early parent-infant interaction influence adults’ relationship with intimate partners. However, human conspecifics socially act towards the real and virtual world in displaying multiple and complex social interactions. Hence, the mechanisms underlying the virtual social relationship in humans remain largely unknown. We hypothesized interaction between genetic factors (three polymorphisms from the oxytocin receptor, OXTR, and the serotonin transporter, 5-HTTLPR), parental bonding patterns (PBI) and adults’ interactional patterns (ASQ, ECR-R) in shaping virtual social behaviour (Instagram, Facebook). Self-reported questionnaires were used to evaluate participants’ (n= 61) parental bonding patterns (Parental Bonding Instrument, formed by four subscales Maternal Care, Paternal Care, Maternal Overprotection, Paternal Overprotection), interactional patterns towards peers (Attachment Style Questionnaire formed by five subscales Confidence, Discomfort in Intimacy, Relationship as Secondary, Need for Approval, Worry about Relationship) and the quality of bond with intimate partners (Experience in Close Relationship Scale formed by two subscales Anxiety, Avoidance). Social media activities were collected applying an automatic Python algorithm through which eight indexes were extracted: Instagram number of following users, followers, posts and tags from other users’ posts and Facebook number of friends, interests, published pics and given likes. Buccal mucosa cell samples were collected to assess participants’ genetic predispositions, and regions OXTR/rs2254298 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers), OXTR/rs53576 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) and 5-HTTLPR/rs255331 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) were genotyped. We hypothesize multiple gene*environment interactions on different parameters and indexes calculated on the social media variables as Instagram Followers/Following ratio (“Social Desirability Index”).

q1.value: The interplay between Oxytocin Receptor Gene and adult close relationship on Instagram behaviour

q2.value: Andrea Bonassi, Ilaria Cataldo, Giulio Gabrieli, Bruno Lepri, Gianluca Esposito

q3.value: In previous studies, we applied a model from behavioural genetics on Instagram and Facebook behaviour. In the context of Instagram, we found that Oxytocin Receptor Gene (OXTR) polymorphism rs2245298 and the quality in the early relationship with the caregivers modulate users' sociability in terms of number of posts and Social Desirability Index (SDI). Despite we revealed a potential influence of individual development on Instagram social behaviour, the impact of quality in the relationship with the partner has not yet been examined under a gene-environment perspective. This research approaches this issue by investigating how the interaction between genetic factors (OXTR/rs2254298, OXTR/rs53576) and adult bonding with intimate partners (Anxiety, Avoidance) shapes virtual social behaviour on Instagram (number of published posts, followers, followings and the SDI, calculated by the ratio between the number of followers and the number of followings). Given that human behaviours are the effect of specific interactions between genes and life experiences, the question remains if Instagram social behaviour of vulnerable genetic carriers is modulated by the relationship with the partner in adulthood.

q4.value:
For each Instagram dependent variable, we hypothesize an interaction between genetic factors and adult attachment scores. Specifically, independently from gender, we predict that 1) adult Instagram users with genetic risk factor (OXTR rs224529 A carriers, OXTR rs53576 G carriers) and a positive and comforting relationship with the partner (Low Avoidance, Low Anxiety) will show a higher number of posts and SDI compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers (OXTR rs224529 G/G homozygotes, OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes). Oppositely, 2) adult users with genetic risk factor and a negative and frustrating relationship with the partner (High Avoidance, High Anxiety) will show a lower number of posts and a lower SDI compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers
Different theoretical and analytical considerations persuade us to test our hypothesis limited to the Instagram number of posts and SDI. Firstly, the number of posts explicitly indicates the amount of shared content among the following people. We consider it an objective parameter of the individual tendency to publish content and broadcast information among users. Moreover, the SDI provides an estimate of the balance between the number of followers and followings for each account. In a previous investigation, we calculated this index to obtain a reliable measure of general sociability, described in terms of higher or lower asymmetry of the individual social network. Secondly, the selection of two main dependent variables allows maintaining a conservative approach to data, avoiding extreme corrections due to multiple tests comparison.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a mixed design study with the Instagram social behaviour (number of posts, SDI) values as the dependent variable, the OXTR gene genotype (OXTR rs224529 G/G homozygotes vs. A carriers,  OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes vs. G carriers) as a between-subject factor, and the ECR-R dimensions (Anxiety, Avoidance) as continuous covariates.

q9.value: This study will not require randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Existing data were processed and organized in a database by two experimenters. The access to the final dataframe will be permitted to a unique researcher.

question.value: Before beginning the experiment, each participant signed the informed consent (no-risk warranty, health history and data treatment) for each assessment, providing information about gender, age and ethnicity. First, participants completed an online self-report questionnaire (Experience Close Relationship - Revised) to assess their attachment status with the partner (behavioural assessment). Secondly, a buccal mucosa for DNA analysis sample was collected from each participant by using sterile cotton swabs for genotyping (genetic assessment). Finally, participants provided their own online Instagram link and an ad-hoc Python script extracted three a priori elected parameters representative of the virtual social behaviours (social media assessment). When the automatic script failed, Instagram data were collected manually.

q13.value: Non-parent adults (n = 61) aged 18-26 were recruited among the students of the Nanyang Technological University (Singapore). All participants were Singaporean. Exclusion criteria were: (I) current or lifetime history of genetic, neurological or psychiatric disorder, (II) age higher than 30 years, (III) not being Instagram users. Four participants were not included due to failure in a) questionnaires' online compilation or b) Instagram data extraction. In the end, our sample consisted of 57 Singaporean adults (16 males). The Ethical Committee of Nanyang Technological University approved the research (IRB-2015-08-020-01), which was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Bio-samples containing buccal mucosa were anonymized and sent to the laboratory for genetic assessment. Instagram data and questionnaire data were anonymized at the beginning of the early data collection.

q14.value: Considering that study constraints influence the sample size during the data collection, we calculated the effect size by implementing sensitivity power analysis in GPower software for Instagram number of posts and SDI respectively. In the sensitivity analysis, we considered analysis of covariance (ANCOVA: fixed effects, main effects and interactions). Input parameters corrected the alpha at 0.025 and set Power at 0.80, total sample size at 57, numerator degrees of freedom at 1, number of groups at 2, number of covariates at 2. After the calculation, the output parameters showed a large effect size (0.42). This parameter is in line with previous studies which found a statistical power equal between 0.90 and 0.99 given a large effect size (for example, see Bonassi et al., 2019). Moreover, interaction effects between adult attachment and genotype will be also analyzed by two Student's t-test. Given that the researcher has not yet permitted to access the dataset, it is not possible to estimate the sample size of the two comparing groups required for a sensitivity analysis (corrected alpha at 0.025, expected Power at 0.80). Therefore, for each significant gene*environment interaction the power of two one-tailed Student's t-tests (the difference between two independent means) will be calculated post-hoc.

q15.value: As many participants as possible were sampled in three months.

question.value: This is an observational study. Therefore, manipulated variables were not included.

We collected genetic, environmental and Instagram (IG) data as hypothesis-driven measured variables.
A detailed description of the measured genetic and environmental variables follows:
1) Environmental measure from adult life experiences: Close Relationship. The Experience in Close Relationships - Revised  (ECR-R) is a 36-item self-report questionnaire commonly adopted to measure the individual self-perception of adult attachment with an intimate partner. Two ECR-R Dimensions were evaluated and considered: 
a) ECR-R Anxiety is an integer variable which reports the ECR-R scores for the Anxiety Dimension.
b) ECR-R Avoidance is an integer variable which reports the ECR-R scores for the Avoidance Dimension.
2) Genetic measure: Oxytocin Receptor Gene. The regions rs2245298 and rs53576 of the Oxytocin Receptor Gene (OXTR) were a-priori considered because of their robust correlation with social behaviour, empathy, affect and adult attachment.
a) OXTR rs53576 is a categorical variable (levels: A/A, A/G, G/G). contains the genotypes for the OXTR region rs53576.
b) OXTR 2254298 is a categorical variable (levels: A/A, G/A, G/G). includes the genotypes for the OXTR region 2254298.
3) An ad-hoc prepared Python script extracted three a-priori elected parameters representative of the Instagram (IG) social behaviours. 
The following two parameters represent the main measured dependent variables included in the confirmatory analyses of this study:
a) IG posts is an integer variable which contains the Instagram number of published posts.
b) IG SDI is an integer variable which includes the estimate produced by the ratio between the number of followers and followings.
The following measured dependent variables are reported for exploratory analyses and unexpected effects of this study:
a) IG followings is an integer variable which includes the Instagram number of followed users.
b) IG followers is an integer variable which includes the Instagram number of followers.

Every variable extracted from Instagram represents a snapshot of participants' social behaviour at a specific time point. As described above, one index will be calculated for the confirmatory analyses: the SDI.

We hypothesized two genotype*environment interactions (OXTR rs2254298 SNP * reported adult attachment and OXTR rs53576 SNP * reported adult attachment) on IG number of posts and SDI. 
The genetic variables, respectively OXTR rs2245298 and OXTR rs53576, will be used in the separated analysis as predictors of the measured variables IG posts and IG SDI, while the ECR-R subscales will be considered as covariates. Statistical analysis will be conducted by R software. 
Data approach and statistical techniques will follow these steps: 
a) Dataset will be imported in R and NA values will be quantified for each variable.
b) Data related to subjects with NA values higher than 2 will be discarded.
c) Genotypes' frequencies for the regions OXTR rs53576 (A/A vs. A/G vs. G/G) and rs2254298 (A/A, G/A, G/G) will be calculated.
d) Participants possessing at least one allele (i.e. G/G homozygotes or A/G) will be classified into a single carriers group and the obtained genotype distribution (i.e. A/A homozygotes vs. G carriers) will be compared with the Hardy–Weinberg Equilibrium.
e) The SDI will be obtained dividing the IG followers by the IG followings.  
f) IG variables will be standardized in z-scores.
g) Male and female participants will be checked for significant differences between the allelic groups and within each IG variable. 
h) In our sample, Cronbach's alphas will be calculated for each subscale of the ECR-R questionnaire. 
i) Prior to data analysis, the data distribution of each dependent variable will be displayed by density plots and box-plots; skew and kurtosis will be calculated to understand the related power values. 
j) To each dependent variable whose sampling will not show a Gaussian distribution, a logarithmic transformation will be applied. Therefore, a statistical parametric test will be adopted.
k) Bartlett test will verify the preliminary assumption of equal variance across the sample for the analysis of covariance (ANCOVA).
l) For each IG variable, one ANCOVA will be performed with the IG posts number as the dependent variable, the OXTR gene genotype (OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes vs. G carriers) as a between-subjects factor and the ECR-R dimensions all together (anxiety, avoidance) as continuous covariates. For each IG variable one ANCOVA was also performed with the OXTr gene genotype rs224529 (G/G homozygotes vs. A carriers) as a between-subjects factor, and the other parameters unchanged.
m) If a gender effect will be preliminarily found on an IG dependent variable, the variable "Gender" will be included as a between-subjects factor in the ANCOVA on the same IG variable. 
n) Correlations will be run as post hoc tests and Pearsons’ r coefficients will be used to measure the strength of the effect of the covariate on the dependent variable and Cohen’s d will be used to evaluate the magnitude of effects which will be found to be significant.
o) Scores in the dimensions of anxiety and avoidance are as a continuum, which will enable us to identify the ECR-R subscales 1) as covariates applied to the ANCOVA, 2) as four main groups by clustering the sample using the median splits for the post-hoc tests: low anxiety, low avoidance, high anxiety, high avoidance.
p) Main and interactive ANCOVA effects between variables will be considered, visualized by scatterplot with linear models.
q) Effects of the interaction between adult attachment and genotype on each IG variable will be represented by barplots and further analyzed by post-hoc t-tests.

q20.value: The dependent variables which will not show a Gaussian data distribution will be log-transformed in order to perform statistical parametric tests. The cubic root data transformation method will be applied if the logarithmic transformation does not properly convert the data distribution into Gaussian with skew contained between -1.5 and 1.5.

q21.value: The probability value for the given parametric statistical models (ANCOVAs) will be used to determine the statistical significance of the results. One-tailed post-hoc Student's t-tests will be preferable if the direction of the effect is clear and in line with the previous hypotheses. Otherwise, two-tailed post-hoc t-tests will be used. Alpha will be corrected proportionally to the number of repeated t-tests by Bonferroni method. Furthermore, Cohen’s d will be calculated to evaluate the magnitude of significant effects in the ANCOVAs and regression coefficients will be applied to analyze the effects of the covariates on the dependent variable.

q22.value: For each dependent variable, data-points which differ in more than two standard deviations from the mean will be identified as outliers and replaced with the mean value in observations excluding outliers.

q23.value: For each variable of each subject incomplete or missing data will be removed.

q24.value: Additional analyses will be conducted on the dependent variables IG followings and IG followers. Data-driven exploration will follow the same procedure adopted for the hypothesis-driven analysis and may produce unexpected and potential main and interactive effects.

g) Male and female participants will be checked for significant differences between the allelic groups and within each IG variable. 
h) In our sample, Cronbach's alphas will be calculated for each subscale of the ECR-R questionnaire. 
i) Prior to data analysis, the data distribution of each dependent variable will be displayed by density plots and box-plots; skew and kurtosis will be calculated to understand the related power values. 
j) To each dependent variable whose sampling will not show a Gaussian distribution, a logarithmic transformation will be applied. Therefore, a statistical parametric test will be adopted.
k) Bartlett test will verify the preliminary assumption of equal variance across the sample for the analysis of covariance (ANCOVA).
l) For each IG variable, one ANCOVA will be performed with the IG posts number as the dependent variable, the OXTR gene genotype (OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes vs. G carriers) as a between-subjects factor and the ECR-R dimensions all together (anxiety, avoidance) as continuous covariates. For each IG variable one ANCOVA was also performed with the OXTr gene genotype rs224529 (G/G homozygotes vs. A carriers) as a between-subjects factor, and the other parameters unchanged.
m) If a gender effect will be preliminarily found on an IG dependent variable, the variable "Gender" will be included as a between-subjects factor in the ANCOVA on the same IG variable. 
n) Correlations will be run as post hoc tests and Pearsons’ r coefficients will be used to measure the strength of the effect of the covariate on the dependent variable and Cohen’s d will be used to evaluate the magnitude of effects which will be found to be significant.
o) Scores in the dimensions of anxiety and avoidance are as a continuum, which will enable us to identify the ECR-R subscales 1) as covariates applied to the ANCOVA, 2) as four main groups by clustering the sample using the median splits for the post-hoc tests: low anxiety, low avoidance, high anxiety, high avoidance.
p) Main and interactive ANCOVA effects between variables will be considered, visualized by scatterplot with linear models.
q) Effects of the interaction between adult attachment and genotype on each IG variable will be represented by barplots and further analyzed by post-hoc t-tests.

q3.value: Previous studies have shown that stronger implicit math male stereotypes corresponded with more negative implicit and explicit math attitudes for women but more positive attitudes for men (Nosek, Banaji, & Greenwald, 2002). The causal influences on implicit attitudes include early experiences, affective experiences, cultural biases, and so on(Rudman, 2004). As we all know, Chinese traditional culture consists a patriarchal tendency which may influence people's attitudes towards men and women. This tendency is more obvious in underdeveloped rural areas than in developed urban areas, although it has changed a lot now. So in this study, I'm interested in whether this culture shapes differences in gender stereotypes about math/art between people living in urban areas and those living in rural areas.

other.value:
•	If participants report that another language than German was spoken at home, levels of instrumental and emotional parentification are expected to be higher compared to participants who negated this question.
•	Exploratively, we will analyze if academics report less instrumental and emotional parentification than non-academics.

dependent.value:
•	Resilience is measured using the German version of the Brief Resilience Scale (BRS) by Chmitorz, Wenzel, Stieglitz, Kunzler, Bagusat, Helmreich, … Tüscher (2018).
•	Self-efficacy is measured using the German Allgemeine Selbstwirksamkeit Kurzskala (ASKU) by Beierlein, Kovaleva, Kemper & Rammstedt (2012).
We added three more items:
“Wenn sich Widerstände auftun, bin ich schnell entmutigt.”, “Für jedes Problem kann ich eine Lösung finden.” and “Schwierigkeiten sehe ich gelassen entgegen, weil ich meinen Fähigkeiten immer vertrauen kann.”. The latter two are taken from the German version of the General Self-Efficacy Scale by Schwarzer & Jerusalem (1999).
•	Satisfaction with Life is measured using the Satisfaction With Life Scale (SWLS) by Diener, Emmons, Larsen & Griffin (1985). We used a German translation by Schumacher (2003).
•	Perceived strain is measured by a self-constructed questionnaire with nine items, the exact wording of the items varies according to the occupational situation of the participant (vocational training/student/dual course of study/employed person).
•	Altruistic work values are measured using the Work Values Inventory by Super (1970). We use the German translation by Seifert & Bergmann (1983). We only measure the scales Altruism, Prestige and Economic Return. The scales Prestige and Economic Return are used as distractors, and relationships with these scales will only be analyzed exploratively.
•	Choice of career is captured by categorizing the sample into field of education/field of occupation (social vs. technical career).
•	Parentification is measured using a self-constructed questionnaire consisting of the facets "instrumental parentification", "emotional parentification" and "perceived fairness". We also added items related to sibling care and the care of relatives and questions regarding potential effects of parentification. Instrumental parentification is also measured by asking for numbers of hours per week during which instrumental tasks are performed (in weeks with high vs. low instrumental work load).
•	Further variables to be assessed are:
-	age
-	gender
-	migration background (measured by two variables)
-	highest educational level
-	final school grade
-	educational situation and field of education
-	occupational situation (if already in employment) and field of occupation
-	presence of younger siblings
-	residence before the age of eighteen
-	parental separation and age when parents separated
-	relationship status of the caring parent (single parent or not)
-	current place of residence
-	presence of a person in the family who needs care
-	current work load (in weeks with high vs. low work load)

conditions.value: There are no specific conditions, the study is correlative. For some analyses, the participants are divided into four groups on the basis of information about their occupational domain: technical and non-academic, technical and academic, social and non-academic and social and academic.

hypothesis.value:
The overall objective of the present study is to develop a German-language questionnaire for the assessment of parentification. The study uses a retrospective self-report by questionnaire to determine how often specific tasks were performed by the participants in their childhood and youth, and examines the relationship with life satisfaction, performance (resilience, self-efficacy, perceived strain and final school grades) and choice of career (social vs. technical). Its scales will be optimized via item selection and their psychometric qualities will be assessed and subsequently the relationships between the different constructs will be examined. 

Hypotheses:

I. Satisfaction with life
•	The relationship between satisfaction with life and instrumental parentification follows an inverted U-shaped pattern: A moderate level of instrumental parentification is associated with high satisfaction with life. Regarding the right end of the distribution, we expect that only very high levels of instrumental parentification lead to a decrease in satisfaction with life.
•	This curvilinear relationship is moderated by perceived fairness: if perceived fairness is high, the relationship between satisfaction with life and instrumental parentification is predominantly positive, while negative if perceived fairness is low.
•	Satisfaction with life and level of emotional parentification correlate negatively. We expect no curvilinear relationship. Higher levels of emotional parentification are associated with lower levels of satisfaction with life.
•	Satisfaction with life and perceived fairness correlate positively.

II. Choice of career
•	Levels of instrumental and emotional parentification correlate positively with reported altruistic work values. Participants who report higher levels of instrumental and/or emotional parentification are expected to also report more altruistic work values compared to participants who reported lower levels of instrumental and/or emotional parentification.
•	Levels of instrumental and emotional parentification are associated with choice of career: Participants who chose a career in the social domain are expected to report higher levels of instrumental and emotional parentification than participants who chose a career in the technical domain.
•	The relationship between perceived fairness and choice of career will be analyzed exploratively.
•	The relationship between perceived fairness and altruistic work values will be analyzed exploratively.

III. Performance
Resilience:
•	The relationship between resilience and instrumental parentification follows an inverted U-shaped pattern: A moderate level of instrumental parentification is associated with high resilience. Regarding the right end of the distribution, we expect that only very high levels of instrumental parentification lead to a decrease in resilience.
•	This curvilinear relationship is moderated by perceived fairness: if perceived fairness is high, the relationship between resilience and instrumental parentification is predominantly positive, while negative if perceived fairness is low.
•	The relationship between emotional parentification and resilience will be analyzed exploratively.
•	Resilience and perceived fairness correlate positively.

Self-efficacy:
•	The relationship between self-efficacy and instrumental parentification follows an inverted U-shaped pattern: A moderate level of instrumental parentification is associated with high self-efficacy. Regarding the right end of the distribution, we expect that only very high levels of instrumental parentification lead to a decrease in self-efficacy.
•	This curvilinear relationship is moderated by perceived fairness: if perceived fairness is high, the relationship between self-efficacy and instrumental parentification is positive, and negative if perceived fairness is low.
•	The relationship between emotional parentification and resilience will be analyzed exploratively. 
•	Self-efficacy and perceived fairness correlate positively.

Perceived strain:
•	The relationship between perceived strain and instrumental parentification follows a U-shaped pattern: A moderate level of instrumental parentification is associated with a lower perceived strain. Regarding the right end of the distribution, we expect that only very high levels of instrumental parentification lead to an increase in perceived strain. Current work load is included as a control variable.
•	Perceived strain and level of emotional parentification correlate positively. Higher levels of emotional parentification are associated with higher levels of perceived strain. Current work load is included as a covariate.
•	Perceived strain and perceived fairness correlate negatively. Higher levels of perceived fairness are associated with lower levels of perceived strain. Current work load is included as a covariate.

Final school grade:
•	The relationship between final school grade and instrumental parentification follows a U-shaped pattern: A moderate level of instrumental parentification is associated with better final school grades. Regarding the right end of the distribution, we expect that only very high levels of instrumental parentification lead to worse final school grades.

q3.value:
This is a Final Year Independent Research Project for 3rd year undergraduate degree in Psychology at Swansea University, UK. 
Title for Ethics application forms and pre-registration: About the environment
Students involved: Danielle Burnett and Kathryn Lock 
Supervisor: Dr Gabriela M. Jiga-Boy, Swansea University, Department of Psychology
Academic year: 2019-2020

PROJECT SYNOPSIS AND RESEARCH QUESTIONS 
With the growing climate crisis, it is important to understand how we can maximise people’s pro-environmental behaviour. Students/young adults may have relatively clear beliefs about how important climate change is for them and/or about what they should do to curb climate change, but they often behave mindlessly, without reference to their personal beliefs. According to Huber, Van Boven, McGraw & Johnson-Graham (2011), causes/crises arousing more immediate emotions are seen as more deserving of attention/help/donations (i.e. immediacy bias). Furthermore, Huber, Van Boven and McGraw (2010) posited that interventions to change behaviour can be external (e.g., choice architecture, incentives) or internal (e.g., encouraging people to monitor/modify their own behaviour). Internal interventions might better correspond to people’s personal beliefs about how such decisions should, normatively, be made. Internally-focused interventions such as introspection are based on people’s internally generated beliefs about how best to make decisions (Van Boven & Huber, NSF grant, 2014). For example, reflecting on how much a policy should be evaluated based on partisanship vs. based on one’s personal attitude leads to less influence of partisanship (Huber et al., 2009, unpublished). Here, we intend to translate this finding to pro- environmental behaviour. We attempt to make people mindful of how they personally believe they should make decisions before they actually make decisions, to increase the intention to behave pro-environmentally. We also attempt to make people aware of their concern for social justice and autonomy motives. We want to get people to make decisions in a manner that more closely matches their personal normative beliefs (assuming these beliefs are correct). We are currently unaware of the extent to which reflection before or after making a pro-environmental decision has on pro-environmental behaviour. Furthermore, we intend to investigate whether reflection may have a higher influence over behaviours regarding sustainable material consumption compared to energy consumption. 

RQ1: Does reflecting about how people personally believe they should act to protect the environment impact their intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour?

RQ2: Do values, environmental concern, awarenss of consequences and negative emotions moderate the relationship between introspection and intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour?

q4.value:
Research Question 1, HYPOTHESIS 1 (directional): We predict that participants who engage in introspection + priming of social justice & autonomy values before choice will report more intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour than those who engage in introspection alone before choice, and that those who engage in introspection alone after choice.

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 1 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who endorse more biospheric values compared to participants who endorse more hedonic and egoistic values.

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 2 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who endorse the new environmental paradigm (NEP) and to less self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who endorse the dominant social paradigm (DSP). 

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 3 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who score higher on awareness of consequences. 

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 4 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who score higher on measures of negative emotions.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (introspection about acting more pro-environmentally) manipulated at 3 levels (Introspect before choice + priming of social justice & autonomy values, Introspect alone before choice, Introspect alone after choice).

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the 3 conditions using Qualtrics' Randomizer function embedded in the survey flow.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from the student population at Swansea University and/or other UK universities. Participants will be recruited using the Psychology Department’s Subject Pool, among friends of the students involved in this project, and directly contacting participants on campus, in public spaces. The study advertisement will be disseminated via email/social media.

If participants are recruited among psychology students, they will be rewarded with 1 credit for every 15 minutes of participation. (note: Undergraduate psychology students need to collect a number of 48 credits from participating in psychology experiments in order to be granted permission to use the Subject Pool for their own research project.) The estimated time needed for completing the survey is 20 minutes, hence we plan to award each participant with 2 credits. If participants are recruited among friends of the students involved in this project, or contacted in public spaces on campus, we plan to offer them chocolates.  

The survey will be administered online, delivered via Qualtrics. Participants will be asked to take part in the study via Swansea University Participant Pool, through social media advertising (Facebook, Instagram & Twitter), or directly on campus in public places. Participants will self-administer the survey from their own location and will be first provided study information, then will be asked to provide consent for taking part. Those who do not consent will be exited the survey. Following consent, participants will fill in demographic measures (age, gender identity, student status), then the values survey, the NEP revised, the awareness of consequences scale, followed by the experimental manipulation. Participants will be randomly allocated to one of the experimental conditions using Qualtrics randomiser function. Following the experimental task, participants will be, debriefed, thanked for their participation and rewarded with course credit, if they are psychology students, or offered chocolates, if they are students from other departments.

q13.value: We plan to collect data from 300 participants. We expect to top up data collection up to 340, in order to make sure that we will have data from approximately 300 participants to conduct analyses in case we need to exclude participants from analyses. In previous experience with a similar sample, we typically had to exclude data from 10% of participants. There are no exclusion rules, but only participants who are 18 years or older will be invited to take part. Timeline: Proposed start: 12 February 2020; End of data collection: 31 March 2020.

We plan to conduct correlation and regression analyses as many variables are continuous. 
Statistical models: 
- Multiple regression with pro-environmental choices and as outcomes, and introspection conditions as predictors. 
- We plan to use contrast analyses to test: 
1) whether the introspection + values and the introspection alone before choice conditions predict more pro-environmental intentions than introspection alone after choice;

registration_responses.q3:
This is a Final Year Independent Research Project for 3rd year undergraduate degree in Psychology at Swansea University, UK. 
Title for Ethics application forms and pre-registration: About the environment
Students involved: Danielle Burnett and Kathryn Lock 
Supervisor: Dr Gabriela M. Jiga-Boy, Swansea University, Department of Psychology
Academic year: 2019-2020

PROJECT SYNOPSIS AND RESEARCH QUESTIONS 
With the growing climate crisis, it is important to understand how we can maximise people’s pro-environmental behaviour. Students/young adults may have relatively clear beliefs about how important climate change is for them and/or about what they should do to curb climate change, but they often behave mindlessly, without reference to their personal beliefs. According to Huber, Van Boven, McGraw & Johnson-Graham (2011), causes/crises arousing more immediate emotions are seen as more deserving of attention/help/donations (i.e. immediacy bias). Furthermore, Huber, Van Boven and McGraw (2010) posited that interventions to change behaviour can be external (e.g., choice architecture, incentives) or internal (e.g., encouraging people to monitor/modify their own behaviour). Internal interventions might better correspond to people’s personal beliefs about how such decisions should, normatively, be made. Internally-focused interventions such as introspection are based on people’s internally generated beliefs about how best to make decisions (Van Boven & Huber, NSF grant, 2014). For example, reflecting on how much a policy should be evaluated based on partisanship vs. based on one’s personal attitude leads to less influence of partisanship (Huber et al., 2009, unpublished). Here, we intend to translate this finding to pro- environmental behaviour. We attempt to make people mindful of how they personally believe they should make decisions before they actually make decisions, to increase the intention to behave pro-environmentally. We also attempt to make people aware of their concern for social justice and autonomy motives. We want to get people to make decisions in a manner that more closely matches their personal normative beliefs (assuming these beliefs are correct). We are currently unaware of the extent to which reflection before or after making a pro-environmental decision has on pro-environmental behaviour. Furthermore, we intend to investigate whether reflection may have a higher influence over behaviours regarding sustainable material consumption compared to energy consumption. 

RQ1: Does reflecting about how people personally believe they should act to protect the environment impact their intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour?

RQ2: Do values, environmental concern, awarenss of consequences and negative emotions moderate the relationship between introspection and intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour?
registration_responses.q4:
Research Question 1, HYPOTHESIS 1 (directional): We predict that participants who engage in introspection + priming of social justice & autonomy values before choice will report more intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour than those who engage in introspection alone before choice, and that those who engage in introspection alone after choice.

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 1 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who endorse more biospheric values compared to participants who endorse more hedonic and egoistic values.

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 2 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who endorse the new environmental paradigm (NEP) and to less self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who endorse the dominant social paradigm (DSP). 

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 3 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who score higher on awareness of consequences. 

Research Question 2, HYPOTHESIS 4 (directional): We predict that introspection regarding pro-environmental decisions would lead to more self-reported intentions to engage in pro-environmental behaviour for participants who score higher on measures of negative emotions.

registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited from the student population at Swansea University and/or other UK universities. Participants will be recruited using the Psychology Department’s Subject Pool, among friends of the students involved in this project, and directly contacting participants on campus, in public spaces. The study advertisement will be disseminated via email/social media.

If participants are recruited among psychology students, they will be rewarded with 1 credit for every 15 minutes of participation. (note: Undergraduate psychology students need to collect a number of 48 credits from participating in psychology experiments in order to be granted permission to use the Subject Pool for their own research project.) The estimated time needed for completing the survey is 20 minutes, hence we plan to award each participant with 2 credits. If participants are recruited among friends of the students involved in this project, or contacted in public spaces on campus, we plan to offer them chocolates.  

The survey will be administered online, delivered via Qualtrics. Participants will be asked to take part in the study via Swansea University Participant Pool, through social media advertising (Facebook, Instagram & Twitter), or directly on campus in public places. Participants will self-administer the survey from their own location and will be first provided study information, then will be asked to provide consent for taking part. Those who do not consent will be exited the survey. Following consent, participants will fill in demographic measures (age, gender identity, student status), then the values survey, the NEP revised, the awareness of consequences scale, followed by the experimental manipulation. Participants will be randomly allocated to one of the experimental conditions using Qualtrics randomiser function. Following the experimental task, participants will be, debriefed, thanked for their participation and rewarded with course credit, if they are psychology students, or offered chocolates, if they are students from other departments.
